bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, June 18, 1928

div1.p: Carter explains her work on the bibliography for the History of Yellow and will update Russell on incidental expenses. Carter's illnesses have also caused her to spend from the savings Henry Rose Carter left her.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, June 18, 1928

opener.dateline:
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
June 18, 1928.

div1.p:
Miss Brown and I have put in another iinstensive week's work on the
bibliography of the History of Yellow Fever. The Library of Congress
closes at 1 P. M. on Saturdays during the summer, but Miss Brown has
a pass, which enables her to stay after closing time, and she generally
can give me six to eight hours work on Saturday. Last week, in addition
to working for me all Saturday afternoon, she came to my apartment in the
evening and we worked together until 10 P. M. I also worked with an ex-
pert proof reader a good part of yesterday (Sunday) checking quotations
in Spanish and Maya and verifying their pagination.

I don't think one could keep on indefinitely at the rate at which
we are now working, but one can do a good deal in an emergency, and I am
not only willing, but glad, to draw on whatever I have of physical re-
serve in order to hasten the work. Incidentally, I haven't yet taken
time to make out my expense accounts for incidental expenses (re the book), but will try
to do so next Sunday morning (I'm working at the Library that afternoon).
I hate to take any time when I could be working on the book for such de-
tails, but my sickness of last summer and again this year have made quite
a hole in what Father left me. That, however, is the least of my troubles:
The thing that hurts is the delay it has caused to the work onthe book.
However, we are certainly making unusually good progress for the class of
work in which we are now engaged, and I feel that the end is in sight, al-
though one can't make definite predictions as to exact time with so “chancey”
a thing as bibliography.
div1.closer:
With very best wishes, I remain
Very truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell, Director,
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation, 61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
